tossups.question: An official from this country was called “the best Foreign Minister in the world” by Foreign Policy in 2009, a year after he nearly tanked the Doha Round by comparing US and EU negotiators to Joseph Goebbels. A corporation in this country lost 25% of its stock value after a 2019 dam failure buried a town in a horrifying red wave of mining waste. This first developing country to pursue large-scale HIV drugs provided foreign aid for the first public antiretroviral drug factory in Africa. This home of Ceslo Amorin and Vale S.A. is the only Western (*) Hemisphere member of the IBSA Forum, where its foreign lending model has been key to the South-South partnership, particularly in southern Africa. This country’s constitution references “development” a staggering fifty times, reflecting a focus on statebuilding and soft power embodied by Baron Rio Branco. This country’s Fome Zero initiative includes its hallmark state welfare program, the Bolsa Família. For 10 points, name this country whose development achievements persistently annoy right-wing president Jair Bolsonaro.
tossups.answer: Federative Republic of Brazil [or República Federativa do Brasil] <Modern World>

tossups.question: This functionality can be synthesized through rhodium-catalyzed C-H insertion of a di·azo·amide carbene, a strategy pioneered by Doyle. The first method to produce compounds with this functionality used a DCC coupling in basic conditions, and dioxane solvent between an alpha-amido·carboxylic acid and a nitrogen- and sulfur-containing saturated ring; that synthesis was completed by Sheehan in 1957. This functionality is biosynthesized by (*) NRPS from L-aminoadipic acid, L-cysteine, and D-valine with a final IPNS-catalyzed condensation step. A strategy for producing this moiety performs a 2+2 cycloaddition between a ketene and an imine and is named for Staudinger. Compounds with this moiety form a covalent bond to an enzyme responsible for crosslinking D-alanine-D-alanine peptide chains; that enzyme is DD-transpeptidase. For 10 points, name this moiety present in the carbapenem, cephalosporin, and penicillin antibiotics, which is distinguished by a four-membered cyclic amide group.
tossups.answer: beta-lactam [or beta-lactam antibiotics; prompt on lactam] <Science - Chemistry>

tossups.question: This musician has been the subject of a series of biopics by Christopher Nupen, and was prominently featured in Nupen’s landmark concert film The Trout. This musician plays infamously flat on much of a 1971 recording of the Franck and Chopin Sonatas. After trying to study with this musician, Ofra Harnoy settled for lessons with this musician’s teacher, William Pleeth. This musician’s main instrument was purchased by Lynn Harrell. The controversial memoir A Genius in the Family was written by this musician’s flutist sister (*) Hilary. This musician came to prominence with a 1965 recording under Sir John Barbirolli, but stopped performing only eight years later. Until 1970, this musician played the Davidov Strad now used by Yo-Yo Ma. Daniel Barenboim married—for 10 points—what multiple sclerosis-stricken English cellist famed for her recordings of the Elgar Cello Concerto?
tossups.answer: Jacqueline (Mary) du Pré <Arts - Auditory>

tossups.question: This thinker turned to neurophilosophy to examine the impact of near-death experiences on decision-making, a project undertaken after he abandoned an over 1000-page project on Kant. This philosopher noted that the “dot over the ‘i’” ultimately broke him while contemplating an interpretation of time embodied by “Jeremy Bearimy.” A 3-hour YouTube video features this thinker attempting to answer T. M. Scanlon’s question “What Do We Owe to Each Other” at St. John’s University in Australia. This philosopher, who once delivered a lecture while adding (*) Peeps marshmallows to a large bowl of chili, required 82 minutes to select a hat during a trial in which one of his companions was forced to play against Blake Bortles on Madden. Human entrails flew into this philosopher’s mouth after he was forced to carry out repeated real-life instances of the Trolley Problem by Michael, a demon who tortures this philosopher along with Jason Mendoza and Eleanor Shellstrop. For 10 points, name this William Jackson Harper-portrayed philosopher on The Good Place.
tossups.answer: Chidi Anagonye <Mythology and Other>

tossups.question: An author with this last name responded to The Birth of a Nation by writing the anti-lynching play Rachel. In Lift Up Thy Voice, Mark Perry describes how two free individuals with this surname, Francis and Archibald, were claimed as slaves by their half-brother Montague before becoming leading members of the early NAACP. The journals of Charlotte Forten, who married into a family with this name, are an important primary source of antebellum life. An activist with this last name defended the right of women to speak in public in the feminist tract Letters on the Equality of the Sexes. (*) Theodore Weld worked with members of a family with this surname to compile testimony showing the brutal conditions of slavery for the book American Slavery As It Is. After becoming Quakers, those individuals with this surname moved from South Carolina to the North and wrote pamphlets like An Appeal to the Christian Women of the South. For 10 points, name this family which included the abolitionist sisters Sarah and Angelina.
tossups.answer: Grimké family <History - American>

tossups.question: A performer in one of this group’s musical traditions provided the vocals for the song “Passion” on Peter Gabriel’s soundtrack to The Last Temptation of Christ. A musical tradition among some members of this group often features the audience showering money on the performers in a practice called vel, and features a group of vocalists called a “party.” A devotional practice among this group involves clothing like the white frock tannūr and the long-sleeved destegul, as well as a tall, somewhat pill-shaped (*) cap called a sikke. Many of this group’s practices are designed to rid observers of the nafs, or “self.” Devotional ceremonies held by this group are called sama. Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan performs a style of music in this devotional tradition called Qawwali. For 10 points, name this group whose Mevlevi order is known as the “Whirling Dervishes.”
tossups.answer: (Indian) Sufism [accept Mevlevis; prompt on Muslims] <Religion>

tossups.question: In one of this author’s poems, a couple dancing to a country-and-western band leads the speaker to reminisce “America—your stupidity. I could almost love you again.” This author spent forty years working on a book-length poem which repeats the italicized phrase “walking on walking” and is named for a Chinese scroll painting. A book by this author of “I Went into the Maverick Bar” and Mountains and Rivers Without End ends with the manifesto “Four Changes,” and includes a poem pledging allegiance to the (*) soil of the title ecosystem “with joyful interpenetration for all.” A character based on this author prophecies a coming “rucksack revolution,” and climbs the Matterhorn along with Ray Smith. This author spent years living in Japan studying Zen Buddhism, and was the model for Japhy Ryder in The Dharma Bums. For 10 points, identify this Beat generation poet who used a Native American name for North America to title his collection Turtle Island.
tossups.answer: Gary Snyder <Literature - American>

tossups.question: A system based on this position is subject to a statement of negative translation known as Glivenko’s theorem. A book on the “Elements” of this position includes a section considering the deduction theorem and the cut-elimination theorem of Gerhard Gentzen, and was written by Michael Dummett. According to this position, the fan theorem is proved using the bar induction technique developed by the philosopher who pioneered this approach. As part of the BHK interpretation, this position argues that the solvability of all mathematical problems is required for the (*) law of the excluded middle to be valid. A middle ground between Platonism and the formalism of David Hilbert, this constructivist position was first articulated by L.E.J. Brouwer. For 10 points, name this position in the philosophy of mathematics that holds that math is a creation of the mind.
tossups.answer: mathematical intuitionism [accept intuitionistic logic before “fan theorem”; prompt on mathematical constructivism] <Philosophy>

tossups.question: The HLA-DQB1-star-06-colon-02 allele increases the risk for this disease by a factor of about 2. This condition is characterized by the loss of a population of neurons that are part of a negative feedback loop with melanin-concentrating hormone neurons and GAD65 neurons; that loop is present in the dorsolateral hypothalamus and projects strongly to the locus coeruleus. It’s not alcoholism, but the date rape drug GHB is used as a treatment for this condition. Neurons that are under autoimmune attack in this condition signal via the neuropeptide (*) orexin. One of the diagnostic criteria for this disease is a REM sleep latency of less than 20 minutes, and patients often have sleep latencies measured in seconds. Cataplexy is its most famous symptom, where patients transiently lose muscle tone and immediately and consciously collapse following a strong emotion. For 10 points, name this disorder where patients have overwhelming daytime drowsiness and sudden attacks of sleep.
tossups.answer: narcolepsy <Science - Biology>

tossups.question: An archaeobotanical study at this country’s site of Janruwa C led Katharina Neumann to posit that the shift of the ITCZ around 400 CE caused the decline of an ancient culture located here. While excavating an archeological site in this country, William B. Fagg identified a distinctive kind of shallow, flat-bottomed dish with a deeply scored interior that was dubbed a “pottery grater.” Bernard Fagg was inspired to investigate a culture in this country after seeing a terracotta (*) head that was being used as a scarecrow. A polity based in this modern-day country was supposedly founded by a hero from Baghdad who killed a serpent living in the Kusugu Well in Daura; that man was named Bayajidda. Geomagnetic surveys at this country’s site of Taruga revealed furnaces used as long as 2500 years ago for iron smelting. For 10 points, name this African country, home to the Nok culture on the Benue Plateau and the Hausa States around Kano, its second largest city behind Lagos.
tossups.answer: Nigeria <History - Other/World>

tossups.question: In John Skelton’s The Garland of Laurel, Dame Pallas defends Skelton’s poetry to a queen personifying this concept. In another poem, a woman personifying this concept bears the names and arms of Alexander and Hercules on her shoulders. That woman named for this concept orders Aeolus to blow trumpets called “Clere Laude” and “Sklaunder” to spread her decisions to the world. After the speaker of “Lycidas” calls this concept “the spur that the clear spirit doth raise” to “scorn delights and live laborious days,” Phoebus replies that it only comes from the (*) judgment of Heaven. A fourteenth-century poem named for this concept begins with the narrator’s dream-vision of a glass temple, where he reads a tablet telling the story of The Aeneid. In that poem, a building representing this concept is held up by columns which support figures like Lucan and Ovid. For 10 points, name this type of poetic immortality personified in a Geoffrey Chaucer poem about its House.
tossups.answer: fame [or fama; accept The House of Fame] <Literature - British>

tossups.question: A holder of this non-Russian position came to power after publishing the article “Who Is to Blame?” and launched an ambitious canal project that led to national bankruptcy under the mismanagement of István Türr. That man alternated holding this office with a rival who was later stabbed by a vagrant enraged at his ordinance closing down gambling houses. Military leaders opposed to another holder of this office were executed in the Trial of the Six. That man had his efforts to maintain neutrality thwarted in the Noemvriana, or “November Events,” which created the (*) National Schism during World War I between that holder of this office and his king. The Goudi coup brought to power the most famous holder of this position, which was converted into an autocracy in the 4th of August Regime of a man who replied “Okhi,” or “no!” to Mussolini’s request to station troops in his country. For 10 points, name this position held by Ioannis Metaxas and Eleftherios Venizelos, who led governments from Athens.
tossups.answer: Prime Minister of Greece [because Greece is weird, you can actually also take President of the Government of Greece; prompt on partial answer] <History - European>

tossups.question: A model of particle diffusion between two containers that obeys the H-theorem is named for this man. A general case of this man’s identity can be derived by taking the time-derivative of the bra-ket “psi, A-hat, psi” and showing that this term is the sum of an expectation of a commutator and the expectation of a time derivative; the Hellman–Feynman theorem is a special case of that identity. This man co-names a theorem with Richard Tolman that states that temperature varies with spacetime curvature. This scientist housed both Einstein and Bohr while they debated quantum mechanics in Leiden. This man first articulated that systems where the (*) heat capacity is discontinuous observe a second-order phase transition, in his classification of phase transitions. This scientist coined the term “spinor,” and his theorem states that the position and momentum quantum mechanical operators obey Newton’s second law. For 10 points, name this Austrian physicist who names a paradox showing that Born rigidity doesn’t agree with special relativity for the case of a rigid disc.
tossups.answer: Paul Ehrenfest <Science - Physics>

tossups.question: In 1958, Kenneth Tynan touched off the so-called “London Controversy” by writing a brutally negative review of this author’s plays. For the past 70 years, two of this author’s early plays have been permanently staged by the Théâtre de la Huchette in Paris. Many of this author’s plays depict the irrational growth or proliferation of material things, such as a gentleman trapped in his apartment beneath an ever-increasing pile of furniture, or an expanding (*) corpse whose feet burst through a door. This author’s first play, which was originally directed by Nicholas Bataille, includes characters who repeat lines like “How curious, how bizarre, what a coincidence!” This author of The New Tenant and Amédée turned the sentences in an English textbook into a play about the breakdown of language between the Martins and the Smiths. For 10 points, name this absurdist playwright of The Bald Soprano.
tossups.answer: Eugène Ionesco <Literature - European>

tossups.question: In one book, this author asserted that “it was necessary to resort to mysterious means which I believed were the divination of the Whole Truth” in order to reach the title place. Two cats named Marmeen and Tchatcha befriend the protagonist of one of this author’s novels while she stays with her son Galahad. This author wrote about how her stomach became the “mirror of the earth” in a memoir that details being drugged with cardiazol after being deemed “incurably insane.” This author of (*) Down Below was the subject of a 2011 novel by her friend Elena Poniatowska, whose book Lilus Kikus is illustrated by her drawings. She wrote a novel in which Marian Leatherby eavesdrops on her family’s plans to send her to a retirement home by using the title device. For 10 points, name this author of The Hearing Trumpet, an English-born Mexican author better known for her surrealist paintings.
tossups.answer: Leonora Carrington <Literature - Other/World>

tossups.question: A short film by this artist interrupts shots of a woman walking a tightrope with bird’s-eye shots of people hula-hooping. In another film by this artist, the screen is mostly filled with empty sky, while the artist’s head bobs up and down at the bottom of the frame. This artist created 155 sheets of stamps to commemorate soldiers killed in the Iraq War in his work Queen and Country. This creator of Five Easy Pieces and Just Above My Head won the 1999 Turner Prize for the film Deadpan, beating out (*) Tracey Emin’s My Bed. In a 2008 film, this director included a 17-minute still shot of a priest and a prisoner sharing a pack of cigarettes while debating the morality of the prisoner’s actions. For 10 points, name this British director who cast Michael Fassbender as Bobby Sands in Hunger, a sex addict in Shame, and Edwin Epps—the owner of Solomon Northrup—in 12 Years a Slave.
tossups.answer: Steve McQueen [or Steven Rodney McQueen] <Arts - Audiovisual, Other>

tossups.question: Ronald Krebs argued that a notable shift in how this activity was conducted occurred not because of a negative shock, but rather because of positive confidence, in a book about “Narrative and the making of [this].” Stephen Krasner objected to a notable work examining different explanations for this activity in an essay placing its author “in Wonderland.” That 1971 book puts forth three potential models for this collective activity––the rational actor model, the organizational process model, and the governmental politics model––and uses each to analyze a pivotal (*) event from the previous decade. Philip Zelikow helped rewrite a 1999 update of that book about different models for this activity, Graham Allison’s Essence of Decision, after the EXCOMM tapes were declassified. This activity names a magazine that publishes an annual “Top 100 Global Thinkers” list, and has a log featuring two white letters on a red background. For 10 points, identify this activity that encompasses the positions and decisions a country uses in its relations with other countries, as opposed to its “domestic” counterpart.
tossups.answer: Foreign Policy [accept synonyms like Foreign Affairs until “Top 100”, but not after; prompt on International Politics, International Security, or similar answers; prompt on answers about government/bureaucratic/political decision-making with “in what area?”] <Social Science>

tossups.question: A photographer from this country depicted two aluminum trash cans colliding in midair in a 1972 photo taken in Indian Village, New Mexico. A photographer from this country is best-known for the abstract series Man and Woman and for using often surreal montages in Ordeal by Roses, which depicts a writer from this country. In another photograph from this country, a woman holding a microphone grimaces while the photographer sticks a beer bottle out from the crotch of his jeans. That photographer from this country placed a plastic triceratops on the ground in an infamous photo of a dangling nude with a (*) flower inserted into her vagina. That photographer from this country has, unsurprisingly, been the subject of protests due to sexual exploitation of the models for his many near-pornographic depictions of traditional rope bondage. For 10 points, name this home of Eikoh Hosoe and Nobuyoshi Araki.
tossups.answer: Japan [or Nippon; or Nihon] (The first photographer is Ikko Narahara.) <Arts - Visual>

tossups.question: Interferometric readout from this class of devices is often done by coupling them with VCSELs, or vertical-cavity surface-emitting lasers. The LIGA process is part of the HARM, or high-aspect ratio techniques for producing these devices; those processes use UV- or X-ray photosensitive materials and high-energy lasers for lithography. In biology, lab-on-a-chip devices and substrates patterned to grow tissues and isolate single cells are examples of this class of devices. The cantilever of an atomic force microscopy probe is part of this class of devices. DLP projectors use this technology in their DMD component; that component involves millions of micromirrors that are (*) actuated using this technology. These devices, which are often created through bulk or surface micromachining, are often made up of layers of motors, actuators, and linkages connected to a silicon substrate. For 10 points, name these devices with moving parts created through microfabrication, which are used in applications like accelerometers and biosensors.
tossups.answer: MEMS [or micro·electro·mechanical systems, or nano·electro·mechanical systems, or NEMS; accept micro·opto·electro·mechanical systems or MOEMS; prompt on nanotechnology or semiconductor devices] <Science - Other>

tossups.question: A member of this family died on a voyage along with his sort-of successor, Dodmore Cotton, leaving their fates to be relayed by Thomas Herbert. A meeting in Rome between actor Will Kempe and a member of this family led him to be alluded to as a “fencer to the Sophy” in Twelfth Night. The arrest of two members of this family helped prompt Parliament to publish The Form of Apology and Satisfaction, aimed at King James. A member of this family married a Circassian noblewoman named Teresia (*) Sampsonia, with whom he was painted by Anthony van Dyck. The best-known action taken by members of this family was part of a larger effort by Allahverdi Khan, who greatly expanded the number of ghulam soldiers to make use of the hundreds of cannons that members of this family helped acquire. For 10 points, give this shirname of Robert and Anthony, English adventurers who were ordered by Shah Abbas I to help modernize the Safavid army.
tossups.answer: Shirley <History - Mediterranean+>   Chicago Open 2019: What If We Kissed 😳 in the Non-Western Art Distribution 😳  Edited by Chris Ray, Jacob Reed, Alston Boyd, Will Holub-Moorman, Jonathan Magin, and Sriram Pendyala, with contributions by Wonyoung Jang and Michael Kearney.  Packet by No Powers Please, We’re Post Quizbowl! (Jason Asher, Will Bordowitz, Brian Kalathiveetil, Jonathan Mishory) and Weijia ‘gainst the Aseem (Weijia Cheng, Aseem Keyal, Stephen Liu, Graham Reid)  Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: Description acceptable. The faces of many figures in this set are hidden within heavy, bunched-up drapery. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Dijon mourners [or Dijon pleurants; or mourners for Philip the Bold]
parts: Name this set that once contained 82 alabaster sculptures about a foot and a half tall. Most of the figures depicted in this set are Carthusian monks.
Most of the Dijon mourners were made by this Burgundian sculptor who also created the Well of Moses.

Sluter’s tradition of Gothic sculpture was pioneered by the naturalistic sculptures in this cathedral’s south transept portal. This cathedral near Paris suffered a devastating fire in 1194, but its 13th-century stained glass is intact, alongside its many flying buttresses and asymmetrical spires.

bonuses.leadin: A rudimentary form of this process can rely on 1-bit or 2-bit saturating counters based on past code paths. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: branch prediction [do not accept or prompt on “branch target prediction”]
parts: Name this technique that’s combined with speculative execution to make code with conditionals run more efficiently. When incorrect, this technique can cause the processor to waste tens of clock cycles.
Branch prediction is one of the most widely implemented optimizations in this technique, which breaks up the execution of instructions into multiple stages so they can be performed in parallel.
Rudimentary branch prediction can be improved by using one of these predictors, which take the results of a local predictor and a global predictor and choose one based on past performance.

bonuses.leadin: This historian’s work partially survives through quotations in Josephus’s polemic Against Apion. For 10 points:
parts: Name this Egyptian priest, who was commissioned to write a history of Egypt called the Aegyptiaca during the Ptolemaic period. This historian divided the history of Egypt into thirty dynasties of mortal kings.

Josephus quoted Manetho while arguing for the antiquity of the Jewish people, claiming that this name, translated as “king-shepherd,” referred to ancient Israelites. This name refers to a foreign group of Semitic invaders who introduced the horse and chariot into Egypt.
John Dillery’s book Clio’s Other Sons compares Manetho to this contemporary Babylonian historian, a priest of Bel Marduk who wrote the first comprehensive history of Babylon.

bonuses.leadin: A 2002 book by Randy Martin discusses the childhood of Jonathan Lebed and the website BernieBucks.com to describe this phenomenon in “daily life.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this phenomenon, which the book Capitalizing on Crisis defined as the growing tendency for profit-making in the economy to occur by providing capital for future interest or dividends, rather than through production.
Capitalizing on Crisis is a 2011 book by this economic sociologist at the University of Michigan.
Krippner is a critic of this thinker’s focus on the “embeddedness” of economic activity in non-economic institutions, an idea developed in his book The Great Transformation.

bonuses.leadin: A complex in this city houses a building named for its “dome,” which has been stripped down to exposed metal ribs. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Kenzō Tange [accept names in either order]
Ise [ee-say] Grand Shrine [or Ise jingu] <Arts - Audiovisual, Other>
parts: Name this city that’s home to a park featuring a perpetually-lit flame, a set of three bells, and a saddle-shaped monument in front of a reflecting pool.
The Hiroshima Peace Memorial Park was designed by this architect, who influenced the Metabolists and designed St. Mary’s Cathedral in Tokyo.
Kenzō Tange called this Shinto shrine the “prototype of Japanese architecture” after being asked to design its 59th iteration. This shrine to Amaterasu is torn down and rebuilt every 20 years.

bonuses.leadin: A gay man struggles to remain uninvolved in this conflict in the novel The Stone of Laughter. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: the Lebanese Civil War [or the Civil War in Lebanon; prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this conflict, which corrupts the friendship of two young men in the novel De Niro’s Game and hardens the title veteran of the novel Yalo. The novel Koolaids juxtaposes it with San Francisco during the AIDS crisis.

Koolaids was written by this contemporary Lebanese-American author of The Hakawati. He wrote about a 72-year-old divorcee named Aaliya who translates books like Anna Karenina into Arabic solely for pleasure in his novel An Unnecessary Woman.
Another Lebanese author, Elias Khoury, depicted the struggle of people with this ethnicity in his novel Gate of the Sun. Mahmoud Darwish is often called this ethnicity’s national poet.

bonuses.leadin: Despite his paralysis, this man is able to communicate by blinking his eyes to indicate “Yes” or “No” as Valentine, his granddaughter, spells out words using a dictionary. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this man who protects Valentine from her stepmother’s poison by building up her tolerance to brucine. A Bonapartist letter intended for this man leads his son, Gérard, to send an innocent man to the Château d’If.
Gérard de Villefort unjustly imprisons this Alexandre Dumas character, who enacts bloody revenge after becoming the Count of Monte Cristo.

At the end of The Count of Monte Cristo, Dantès reunites Valentine with her lover, Maximilien, and leaves them a letter telling them that “all human wisdom is contained” in these two verbs. They are also the final words of the novel.

bonuses.leadin: This law can be used to determine the crystal lattice constant based on the angle of X-ray diffraction peaks. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: stress tensor [prompt on partial answer] <Science - Physics>
parts: Name this law that gives the condition for constructive interference in X-rays scattering off a crystal lattice.

These devices, which consist of a piezoelectric transducer producing a traveling wave through a transparent material, are called Bragg cells. Light that hits them undergoes Bragg scattering off sound waves in crystal.

Piezoelectric materials obey the so-called “coupled equations,” one of which states that the D-field is equal to a piezoelectric 3-tensor multiplied by this object. The conservation of angular momentum is equivalent to stating that one of these objects is symmetric.

bonuses.leadin: Clarence Darrow spent just a few months on a review board of this agency, but published three reports condemning it for fostering cartels. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this organization symbolized by a Blue Eagle and created by a similarly-named act that was declared unconstitutional in the Schechter case.

This man was the first director of the NRA and Time’s Man of the Year in 1933. He called for a “blanket code” including a minimum wage, maximum workweek, and abolition of child labor, but was fired in 1934 after handing out leaflets praising Mussolini’s “Corporate State.”

Johnson had earlier joined Henry C. Wallace to support this proposed 1920s bill. This act would have artificially raised prices on farm goods, creating the first farm price supports in U.S. history, but it was vetoed twice by Calvin Coolidge in favor of the Hoover plan.

bonuses.leadin: This play’s main character forces his former friend Wesley to perform a Morris dance in exchange for cocaine. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: “dark Satanic mills” [prompt on partial answer] <Literature - British>
parts: Name this 2009 play by Jez Butterworth about a caravan of misfits led by the aging Johnny “Rooster” Byron, who is being threatened with dispossession by the Kennet and Avon council.
Jerusalem is named for a poem by this author which begins “And did those feet in ancient time / Walk about England’s mountains green.” This mystic also wrote The Marriage of Heaven and Hell.

The second stanza of Blake’s “Jerusalem” asks “And was Jerusalem builded here / among” these places. Critics have usually interpreted these places as references to the factories of the Industrial Revolution.

bonuses.leadin: The Hungarian-born Ibrahim Muteferrika was employed by the Ottoman government to engage in this activity under Ahmad III. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: printing press [accept press; accept printed books, etc. ]
tax-farming [prompt on just taxation or similar answers; accept descriptions like contracting people to collect taxes for you] <History - Other/World>
parts: Identify this activity that André Thevet claimed was banned in the Ottoman Empire by Bayezid II, an idea popularized in modern historiography by Bernard Lewis.

A 1588 firman issued by Murad III allowing the sale of printed books survives in an Arabic copy of Euclid’s Elements published by this merchant family’s “Oriental Press.” This Florentine family’s Tolfa alum mines competed an Ottoman monopoly.

Ottoman antipathy to the printing press may have stemmed from concerns that it would undermine this sort of system, whose examples included the iltizām and malikâne. Under this kind of system, which was essential to Ottoman financial administration, a key government function would be auctioned to the highest bidder.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about JCVI-Syn3.0, a synthetic genome with 531 kbp. For 10 points each:
parts: As a minimal genome, all 473 genes in JCVI-Syn3.0 are essential, despite 126 of said genes having unknown function. This term is used to describe a pair of genes where neither is essential, but deletion of both causes death.
JCVI-Syn3.0 was developed in the lab of J. Craig Venter, who used shotgun sequencing in this project. This project was completed in 2006 and cost 10 billion dollars.
JCVI-Syn3 and JCVI-Syn1 are both derived from the genome of this bacterium. This sexually transmitted pathogen has the smallest known genome of any self-replicating organism.

bonuses.leadin: Events in this city triggered the activism of LeeAnne Walters and were the subject of reports by Mona Hanna-Atisha at the Hurley Medical Center and Virginia Tech’s Marc Edwards. For 10 points:
parts: Name this city, several of whose officials were indicted on criminal charges by Bill Schuette.

Schuette was defeated in the 2018 Michigan gubernatorial election by Gretchen Whitmer, who had defeated this public health professional in the Democratic primary. This man would have been the first Muslim governor in the U.S.

The resignation of John Conyers in Michigan’s 13th district led to the election of this Squad member, a Palestinian-American who along with Ilhan Omar is one of the first two Muslim women ever elected to congress.

bonuses.leadin: This term was first introduced in Espen Aarseth’s book Cybertext. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Joyce [or Michael Joyce or James Joyce] <Literature - American>
parts: Name this mathematical term that Aarseth used to describe works of literature, such as Milorad Pavic’s novel Landscape Painted with Tea, that require “non-trivial effort” for the reader to traverse.

This unusually-structured debut novel by Mark Z. Danielewski is a touchstone of ergodic literature. In it, Johnny Truant discovers the blind Zampanò’s manuscript about a mysterious film called The Navidson Record.

Aarseth devotes a chapter of Cybertext to afternoon, a story, a pioneering example of hypertext fiction written by an American author with this last name. An ergodic novel by another author with this last name describes the relationship of a couple denoted by the initials H.C.E. and A.L.P.

bonuses.leadin: One of these hymns declares that “Serving the Lord is not where, not under the leafy shade,” but that one “Must walk into the prison rooms.” For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Canaan Hymns [or Canaan Songs or Songs of Canaan; or Jiānán Shīxuǎn]
house churches [or home churches; or family churches; or jiātíng jiàohuì]
parts: Name these Chinese-language hymns that were composed by the peasant Lǔ Xiǎomǐn [loo SHYAO-meen]. These pentatonic hymns are often used by underground Christian churches in mainland China.
Underground Christian churches in the People’s Republic of China are denoted by this term, in contrast to government-sponsored churches like those run by the Three-Self Patriotic Movement.

The Three-Self Patriotic Movement was founded by Y.T. Wú, who had earlier worked for this Christian organization, which promoted athletic activities in the early twentieth century as part of “Muscular Christianity,” and which still runs many gyms worldwide.

bonuses.leadin: During Eurovision 2016, Jamala, a singer whose father is from this ethnic group, performed the song “1944,” whose title references the deportation of this ethnic group from their homeland in 1944. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Crimean Tatars [or Qırımtatarlar or qırımlar; prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this ethnic group, a predominantly-Muslim ethnic minority in Ukraine, whose ancestors once allied with the Ottoman Empire as the Crimean Khanate.

The Tatar Mejlis serves as the executive body for this governing body of the Crimean Tatars. Yarliks would often have to be reissued after historical events of this name, many of whose traditions survive in the Naadam festival.

In 1944, the Crimean Tatars were rounded up and forced into cattle trains to be deported at the orders of this NKVD chief, an ethnic Georgia and serial predator who directed the Soviet nuclear weapons program.

bonuses.leadin: The first sentence of this essay describes its title ideology as both action and thought; it later describes the Lictors’ rods as a symbol of unity, strength, and justice. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Doctrine of Fascism [or La dottrina del fascismo]
idealism [or actual idealism; or absolute idealism; or Berkeleyan idealism] <Philosophy>
parts: Name this essay published in 1932 as part of an encyclopedia. The author of its first section on “Fundamental Ideas” had earlier written The Theory of Mind as Pure Act.
The Doctrine of Fascism was partly ghostwritten for Benito Mussolini by this Italian fascist philosopher, who also served as Mussolini’s Minister of Public Education.

Gentile’s fascism was supported by his variant of this position, which stressed the act of thinking. He based his position on Hegel’s “absolute” form of this position, another form of which was proposed by George Berkeley.

bonuses.leadin: A work by this composer opens with a “Hotel Overture” and is bookended by the phrase “It’s again.” For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Jack Bruce [or John Symon Asher Bruce] <Arts - Auditory>
parts: Name this composer of the jazz opera Escalator Over the Hill who co-led the Liberation Music Orchestra with Charlie Haden.
Like her husband Paul, Bley played this instrument, which is also played by Robert Glasper and Chick Corea.
This bassist and singer was a major collaborator on Escalator over the Hill. Between projects as a jazz bassist, this man played bass in the rock supergroup Cream.

bonuses.leadin: The formation of an “ate”-complex intermediate, a radical mechanism, and an S·N·2 mechanism are all theories concerning the mechanism of this reaction. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: pyridine [or pyridinium chlorochromate; prompt on PCC] <Science - Chemistry>
parts: Name this fast metathesis reaction discovered by Wittig. This reaction, which allows the construction of previously-inaccessible organometallic reagents for carbon-carbon bond-forming reactions, is an alternative to adding shavings to the reaction.

In the “lateral-lithiation” of arenes, a Lewis-basic substituent directs the lithium to this position on the arene. This term is used to describe a benzene ring where the two substituent groups are adjacent.
Directed ortho-lithiation of this heterocycle is complicated by 1,2-addition of the reagent into the ring. A chlorochromate salt of this heterocycle is used for gentle oxidation.

bonuses.leadin: The Mutus Liber, which consists only of 15 illustrated plates without any explanatory text, has been interpreted as instructions for creating this object. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Golden [accept The Golden Tripod or The Golden Legend] <History - European>
parts: Name this object of the so-called “Great Work” of alchemy. Sometimes called the “elixir of life,” this object transmutes base metals into gold and grants immortality.

This alchemist from Roman Egypt described the philosopher’s stone as “a stone that is not a stone.” He wrote about the alchemical work of Mary the Prophetess, and shares his name with the Byzantine author of Historia Nova.

Basil Valentinus’s “Twelve Keys” toward creating the philosopher’s stone were included by Michael Maier in a famous alchemical book named for this kind of “Tripod.” This adjective appears in another medieval text that expanded on earlier works by Jean de Mailly and Bartholomew of Trent.
